trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET 5 API app in Visual Studio Code
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET 5 API app in Visual Studio Code

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to create an ASP.NET 5 API app using Visual Studio Code.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to create an ASP.NET 5 API app using Visual Studio Code.

trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET 5 API app in Visual Studio Code
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET 5 API app in Visual Studio Code

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to create an ASP.NET 5 API app using [Visual Studio Code](http://code.visualstudio.com//Docs/whyvscode).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to create an ASP.NET 5 API app using [Visual Studio Code](http://code.visualstudio.com//Docs/whyvscode).

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET 5 is a significant redesign of ASP.NET.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET 5 is a significant redesign of ASP.NET.

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET 5 is a new open-source and cross-platform framework for building modern cloud-based Web applications using .NET.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET 5 is a new open-source and cross-platform framework for building modern cloud-based Web applications using .NET.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Introduction to ASP.NET 5](http://docs.asp.net/en/latest/conceptual-overview/aspnet.html).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Introduction to ASP.NET 5](http://docs.asp.net/en/latest/conceptual-overview/aspnet.html).

trans-unit.source: For information about API apps, see [What are API apps?](app-service-api-apps-why-best-platform.md)
trans-unit.target: For information about API apps, see [What are API apps?](app-service-api-apps-why-best-platform.md)

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To complete this tutorial, you need a Microsoft Azure account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To complete this tutorial, you need a Microsoft Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can [sign up for a free trial](/pricing/free-trial/) or [activate your MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/).
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can [sign up for a free trial](/pricing/free-trial/) or [activate your MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/).

trans-unit.source: You can also try for free the [App Service App Samples](http://tryappservice.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: You can also try for free the [App Service App Samples](http://tryappservice.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: [Node](http://nodejs.org/) is a platform for building fast and scalable server applications using JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: [Node](http://nodejs.org/) is a platform for building fast and scalable server applications using JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Node is the runtime (Node) and [npm](http://www.npmjs.com/) is the Package Manager for Node modules.
trans-unit.target: Node is the runtime (Node) and [npm](http://www.npmjs.com/) is the Package Manager for Node modules.

trans-unit.source: You will use npm to scaffold an ASP.NET 5 API app in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You will use npm to scaffold an ASP.NET 5 API app in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET 5/DNX is a lean .NET stack for building modern cloud and web apps that run on OS X, Linux, and Windows.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET 5/DNX is a lean .NET stack for building modern cloud and web apps that run on OS X, Linux, and Windows.

trans-unit.source: It has been built from the ground up to provide an optimized development framework for apps that are either deployed to the cloud or run on-premises.
trans-unit.target: It has been built from the ground up to provide an optimized development framework for apps that are either deployed to the cloud or run on-premises.

trans-unit.source: It consists of modular components with minimal overhead, so you retain flexibility while constructing your solutions.
trans-unit.target: It consists of modular components with minimal overhead, so you retain flexibility while constructing your solutions.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] ASP.NET 5 and DNX (the .NET Execution Environment) on OS X and Linux are in an early Beta/Preview state.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] ASP.NET 5 and DNX (the .NET Execution Environment) on OS X and Linux are in an early Beta/Preview state.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is designed to get you started building applications with the latest development versions ASP.NET 5 and DNX.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is designed to get you started building applications with the latest development versions ASP.NET 5 and DNX.

trans-unit.source: If you want a more stable, released, experience, go to [http://www.asp.net/vnext](http://www.asp.net/vnext).
trans-unit.target: If you want a more stable, released, experience, go to [http://www.asp.net/vnext](http://www.asp.net/vnext).

trans-unit.source: The following instructions are specific to Windows.
trans-unit.target: The following instructions are specific to Windows.

trans-unit.source: For more detailed installation instructions for OS X, Linux, and Windows, see [Installing ASP.NET 5 and DNX](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/ASPnet5#_installing-aspnet-5-and-dnx).
trans-unit.target: For more detailed installation instructions for OS X, Linux, and Windows, see [Installing ASP.NET 5 and DNX](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/ASPnet5#_installing-aspnet-5-and-dnx).

trans-unit.source: To install .NET Version Manager (DNVM) in Windows, run the following command in the Command Window:
trans-unit.target: To install .NET Version Manager (DNVM) in Windows, run the following command in the Command Window:

trans-unit.source: This will download the DNVM script and put it in your user profile.
trans-unit.target: This will download the DNVM script and put it in your user profile.

trans-unit.source: You may need to log off after entering the above command in order for the change to the PATH environment variable to take effect.
trans-unit.target: You may need to log off after entering the above command in order for the change to the PATH environment variable to take effect.

trans-unit.source: Check the location of DNVM by running the following in the Command Window:
trans-unit.target: Check the location of DNVM by running the following in the Command Window:

trans-unit.source: The Command Window will show a path similiar to the following:
trans-unit.target: The Command Window will show a path similiar to the following:

trans-unit.source: Now that you have DNVM, you need to use it to download DNX in order to run your applications.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have DNVM, you need to use it to download DNX in order to run your applications.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command from the Command Window:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command from the Command Window:

trans-unit.source: Verify your DNVM and view the active runtime by entering the following in the Command Window:
trans-unit.target: Verify your DNVM and view the active runtime by entering the following in the Command Window:

trans-unit.source: The Command Window will show the details of the active runtime:
trans-unit.target: The Command Window will show the details of the active runtime:

trans-unit.source: For more detailed installation instructions for OS X, Linux, and Windows, see [Installing ASP.NET 5 and DNX](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/ASPnet5#_installing-aspnet-5-and-dnx).
trans-unit.target: For more detailed installation instructions for OS X, Linux, and Windows, see [Installing ASP.NET 5 and DNX](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/ASPnet5#_installing-aspnet-5-and-dnx).

trans-unit.source: This section shows you how to scaffold a new app ASP.NET API app.
trans-unit.target: This section shows you how to scaffold a new app ASP.NET API app.

trans-unit.source: You will use the node package manager (npm) to install [Yeoman](http://yeoman.io/), [Grunt](http://gruntjs.com/), and [Bower](http://bower.io/).
trans-unit.target: You will use the node package manager (npm) to install [Yeoman](http://yeoman.io/), [Grunt](http://gruntjs.com/), and [Bower](http://bower.io/).

trans-unit.source: After installing Visual Studio Code and Node.js, open a command prompt with Admin rights and navigate to the location where you want all of your ASP.NET projects using VSCode to be located.
trans-unit.target: After installing Visual Studio Code and Node.js, open a command prompt with Admin rights and navigate to the location where you want all of your ASP.NET projects using VSCode to be located.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following in the command window to install Yeoman and the supporting tools:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following in the command window to install Yeoman and the supporting tools:

trans-unit.source: npm install -g yo grunt-cli generator-aspnet bower
trans-unit.target: npm install -g yo grunt-cli generator-aspnet bower

trans-unit.source: Enter the following in the command window to create the project folder and scaffold the app:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following in the command window to create the project folder and scaffold the app:

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions provided by the generator by scrolling and selecting the **Web API Application** type.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions provided by the generator by scrolling and selecting the **Web API Application** type.

trans-unit.source: Set the name of your new ASP.NET API app to **ContactsList**.
trans-unit.target: Set the name of your new ASP.NET API app to **ContactsList**.

trans-unit.source: This name will be used in code provided later in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This name will be used in code provided later in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Yoman will create a new folder named **ContactsList** and the necessary files for your new app.
trans-unit.target: Yoman will create a new folder named **ContactsList** and the necessary files for your new app.

trans-unit.source: You can open VSCode from the Command Window by entering **code .**.
trans-unit.target: You can open VSCode from the Command Window by entering **code .**.

trans-unit.source: From the **File** menu, select **Open Folder** and select the folder where your ASP.NET API app is located.
trans-unit.target: From the **File** menu, select **Open Folder** and select the folder where your ASP.NET API app is located.

trans-unit.source: VSCode will load your project and display it in the **Explore** window.
trans-unit.target: VSCode will load your project and display it in the **Explore** window.

trans-unit.source: In **VSCode**, from the **View** menu, select **Command Palette**.
trans-unit.target: In **VSCode**, from the **View** menu, select **Command Palette**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Command Palette** enter the following commands:
trans-unit.target: In the **Command Palette** enter the following commands:

trans-unit.source: As you start typing, you will see the full command line from the list.
trans-unit.target: As you start typing, you will see the full command line from the list.

trans-unit.source: The Restore command installs the necessary NuGet packages to run the application.
trans-unit.target: The Restore command installs the necessary NuGet packages to run the application.

trans-unit.source: A command window will display **Restore complete** when ready.
trans-unit.target: A command window will display **Restore complete** when ready.

trans-unit.source: You will now modify the **ContactsList** app by adding a **Contact** class and a **ContactsController** class.
trans-unit.target: You will now modify the **ContactsList** app by adding a **Contact** class and a **ContactsController** class.

trans-unit.source: Place your cursor over the **ContactsList** project name and add a new folder named *Models* using the new folder icon.
trans-unit.target: Place your cursor over the **ContactsList** project name and add a new folder named *Models* using the new folder icon.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the **Models** folder to add a new class file named *Contact.cs* with the following code:
trans-unit.target: Right-click the **Models** folder to add a new class file named *Contact.cs* with the following code:

trans-unit.source: Right-click the **Controllers** folder and add a *ContactsController.cs* file so that it appears as follows:
trans-unit.target: Right-click the **Controllers** folder and add a *ContactsController.cs* file so that it appears as follows:

trans-unit.source: new Contact { Id = 1, EmailAddress = "barney@contoso.com", Name = "Barney Poland"},
trans-unit.target: new Contact { Id = 1, EmailAddress = "barney@contoso.com", Name = "Barney Poland"},

trans-unit.source: new Contact { Id = 2, EmailAddress = "lacy@contoso.com", Name = "Lacy Barrera"},
trans-unit.target: new Contact { Id = 2, EmailAddress = "lacy@contoso.com", Name = "Lacy Barrera"},

trans-unit.source: new Contact { Id = 3, EmailAddress = "lora@microsoft.com", Name = "Lora Riggs"}
trans-unit.target: new Contact { Id = 3, EmailAddress = "lora@microsoft.com", Name = "Lora Riggs"}

trans-unit.source: Make sure all your files are saved by selecting **File** > **Save All**.
trans-unit.target: Make sure all your files are saved by selecting **File** > **Save All**.

trans-unit.source: From the **Command Palette**, enter the following to run the app locally:
trans-unit.target: From the **Command Palette**, enter the following to run the app locally:

trans-unit.source: The command window will display *Started* in it.
trans-unit.target: The command window will display *Started* in it.

trans-unit.source: If the command window doesn't display *Started*, check the lower left corning of VSCode for errors in your project.
trans-unit.target: If the command window doesn't display *Started*, check the lower left corning of VSCode for errors in your project.

trans-unit.source: Open a browser and navigate to the following URL:
trans-unit.target: Open a browser and navigate to the following URL:

trans-unit.source: You can then view the contents of *Contacts.json*.
trans-unit.target: You can then view the contents of *Contacts.json*.

trans-unit.source: When you view the file, you'll see the following content:
trans-unit.target: When you view the file, you'll see the following content:

trans-unit.source: The metadata that enables an ASP.NET API project to be deployed as an API app must be contained in an *apiapp.json* file at the root of the project.
trans-unit.target: The metadata that enables an ASP.NET API project to be deployed as an API app must be contained in an *apiapp.json* file at the root of the project.

trans-unit.source: In VSCode, right-click the *wwwroot* folder select the **New File** option.
trans-unit.target: In VSCode, right-click the *wwwroot* folder select the **New File** option.

trans-unit.source: Make sure *apiapp.json* is in the *wwwroot* folder.
trans-unit.target: Make sure *apiapp.json* is in the *wwwroot* folder.

trans-unit.source: Add the following to the *apiapp.json* file:
trans-unit.target: Add the following to the *apiapp.json* file:

trans-unit.source: In the *apiapp.json* file you can specify an endpoint for dynamic Swagger API definition JSON, but for this tutorial you’ll use a static API definition file.
trans-unit.target: In the *apiapp.json* file you can specify an endpoint for dynamic Swagger API definition JSON, but for this tutorial you’ll use a static API definition file.

trans-unit.source: For an example that uses dynamic Swagger generation, see [Configure a Web API project as an API app](app-service-dotnet-create-api-app-visual-studio.md).
trans-unit.target: For an example that uses dynamic Swagger generation, see [Configure a Web API project as an API app](app-service-dotnet-create-api-app-visual-studio.md).

trans-unit.source: To provide a static Swagger 2.0 API definition file, you must create a folder at the web root and place the API definition file in it.
trans-unit.target: To provide a static Swagger 2.0 API definition file, you must create a folder at the web root and place the API definition file in it.

trans-unit.source: In VSCode, create a folder named *metadata* in the *wwwroot* folder.
trans-unit.target: In VSCode, create a folder named *metadata* in the *wwwroot* folder.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the new *metadata* folder and add a new file named *apiDefinition.swagger.json*.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the new *metadata* folder and add a new file named *apiDefinition.swagger.json*.

trans-unit.source: Add the following json syntax to the new file:
trans-unit.target: Add the following json syntax to the new file:

trans-unit.source: "host": "MUST REPLACE THIS WITH YOUR HOST URL",
trans-unit.target: "host": "MUST REPLACE THIS WITH YOUR HOST URL",

trans-unit.source: Later in this tutorial, you will replace the above host URL placeholder string with your Azure host URL that you will create and copy later.
trans-unit.target: Later in this tutorial, you will replace the above host URL placeholder string with your Azure host URL that you will create and copy later.

trans-unit.source: Create an API app in the Azure preview Portal
trans-unit.target: Create an API app in the Azure preview Portal

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To complete this tutorial, you need a Microsoft Azure account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To complete this tutorial, you need a Microsoft Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can [sign up for a free trial](/pricing/free-trial/) or [activate your MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/).
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can [sign up for a free trial](/pricing/free-trial/) or [activate your MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/).

trans-unit.source: You can also try for free the [App Service App Samples](http://tryappservice.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: You can also try for free the [App Service App Samples](http://tryappservice.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: Log in to the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: Log in to the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: Click **NEW** at the top left of the portal.
trans-unit.target: Click **NEW** at the top left of the portal.

trans-unit.source: Enter a value for **Name**, such as ContactsList.
trans-unit.target: Enter a value for **Name**, such as ContactsList.

trans-unit.source: Select an App Service plan or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Select an App Service plan or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: If you create a new plan, select the pricing tier, location, and other options.
trans-unit.target: If you create a new plan, select the pricing tier, location, and other options.

trans-unit.source: If you left the **Pin to Startboard** check box selected when creating the app, you can easily locate the app by clicking **Home** or **Browse**.
trans-unit.target: If you left the **Pin to Startboard** check box selected when creating the app, you can easily locate the app by clicking **Home** or **Browse**.

trans-unit.source: If you cleared the checkbox, click **Notifications** on the left to see the API app creation status, and click the notification to go to the blade for the new API app.
trans-unit.target: If you cleared the checkbox, click **Notifications** on the left to see the API app creation status, and click the notification to go to the blade for the new API app.

trans-unit.source: Enable Git publishing from the new API app
trans-unit.target: Enable Git publishing from the new API app

trans-unit.source: Git is a distributed version control system that you can use to deploy your Azure Website.
trans-unit.target: Git is a distributed version control system that you can use to deploy your Azure Website.

trans-unit.source: You'll store the code you write for your API app in a local Git repository, and you'll deploy your code to Azure by pushing to a remote repository.
trans-unit.target: You'll store the code you write for your API app in a local Git repository, and you'll deploy your code to Azure by pushing to a remote repository.

trans-unit.source: This method of deployment is a feature of App Service web apps that you can use in an API app because API apps are based on web apps: an API app in Azure App Service is a web app with additional features for hosting web services.
trans-unit.target: This method of deployment is a feature of App Service web apps that you can use in an API app because API apps are based on web apps: an API app in Azure App Service is a web app with additional features for hosting web services.

trans-unit.source: In the portal you manage the features specific to API apps in the **API App** blade, and you manage the features that are shared with web apps in the **API App Host** blade.
trans-unit.target: In the portal you manage the features specific to API apps in the **API App** blade, and you manage the features that are shared with web apps in the **API App Host** blade.

trans-unit.source: So in this section you go to the **API App Host** blade to configure the Git deployment feature.
trans-unit.target: So in this section you go to the **API App Host** blade to configure the Git deployment feature.

trans-unit.source: In the API App blade, click **API App host**.
trans-unit.target: In the API App blade, click **API App host**.

trans-unit.source: Find the **Deployment** section of the **API App** blade and click **Set up continuous deployment**.
trans-unit.target: Find the **Deployment** section of the **API App** blade and click **Set up continuous deployment**.

trans-unit.source: You may need to scroll down to see this part of the blade.
trans-unit.target: You may need to scroll down to see this part of the blade.

trans-unit.source: If you have have not previously set up deployment credentials for publishing an API app or other App Service app, set them up now:
trans-unit.target: If you have have not previously set up deployment credentials for publishing an API app or other App Service app, set them up now:

trans-unit.source: Create a user name and password.
trans-unit.target: Create a user name and password.

trans-unit.source: You'll need this password later when setting up Git.
trans-unit.target: You'll need this password later when setting up Git.

trans-unit.source: In the **API App Host** blade, click **Settings > Properties**.
trans-unit.target: In the **API App Host** blade, click **Settings > Properties**.

trans-unit.source: The URL of the remote Git repository that you'll deploy to is shown under "GIT URL".
trans-unit.target: The URL of the remote Git repository that you'll deploy to is shown under "GIT URL".

trans-unit.source: Copy the **GIT URL** for use later in the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Copy the **GIT URL** for use later in the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, in the **API APP** blade, copy the **URL** that you will use to update the "host" value in the *apiDefinition.swagger.json* file.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, in the **API APP** blade, copy the **URL** that you will use to update the "host" value in the *apiDefinition.swagger.json* file.

trans-unit.source: In VSCode, open the *apiDefinition.swagger.json* file and replace the host value "MUST REPLACE THIS WITH YOUR HOST URL" with the **URL** you copied in the step above.
trans-unit.target: In VSCode, open the *apiDefinition.swagger.json* file and replace the host value "MUST REPLACE THIS WITH YOUR HOST URL" with the **URL** you copied in the step above.

trans-unit.source: Also, remove the "https://" characters from the beginning of the host value.
trans-unit.target: Also, remove the "https://" characters from the beginning of the host value.

trans-unit.source: Save your changes to the *apiDefinition.swagger.json* file.
trans-unit.target: Save your changes to the *apiDefinition.swagger.json* file.

trans-unit.source: Publish your API app to Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Publish your API app to Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: In this section you create a local Git repository and push from that repository to Azure in order to deploy your sample application to the API app running in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: In this section you create a local Git repository and push from that repository to Azure in order to deploy your sample application to the API app running in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: In VSCode on the left navigation bar, select the Git option.
trans-unit.target: In VSCode on the left navigation bar, select the Git option.

trans-unit.source: If Git is not already installed, install it by choosing one of the provided links ([Chocolatey](https://chocolatey.org/packages/git) or [git-scm.com](http://git-scm.com/downloads)).
trans-unit.target: If Git is not already installed, install it by choosing one of the provided links ([Chocolatey](https://chocolatey.org/packages/git) or [git-scm.com](http://git-scm.com/downloads)).

trans-unit.source: If you are new to Git, choose **git-scm.com** and select the option to use Git with GitBash from the Windows Command Prompt.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to Git, choose **git-scm.com** and select the option to use Git with GitBash from the Windows Command Prompt.

trans-unit.source: Once Git is installed, restart VSCode and select the Git option on the left bar.
trans-unit.target: Once Git is installed, restart VSCode and select the Git option on the left bar.

trans-unit.source: In VSCode, select **Initialize git repository** to make sure your workspace is under git source control.
trans-unit.target: In VSCode, select **Initialize git repository** to make sure your workspace is under git source control.

trans-unit.source: Add a commit message and select the **Commit All** check.
trans-unit.target: Add a commit message and select the **Commit All** check.

trans-unit.source: As an alternative, you can use the Windows Command Prompt.
trans-unit.target: As an alternative, you can use the Windows Command Prompt.

trans-unit.source: In **GitBash**, change folders to your VSCode project folder.
trans-unit.target: In **GitBash**, change folders to your VSCode project folder.

trans-unit.source: Create a remote reference for pushing updates to the web app (API app host) you created previously, using the Git URL (ending in ".git") that you copied earlier:
trans-unit.target: Create a remote reference for pushing updates to the web app (API app host) you created previously, using the Git URL (ending in ".git") that you copied earlier:

trans-unit.source: git remote add azure [URL for remote repository]
trans-unit.target: git remote add azure [URL for remote repository]

trans-unit.source: Push your changes to Azure by entering the following command:
trans-unit.target: Push your changes to Azure by entering the following command:

trans-unit.source: You are prompted for the password you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: You are prompted for the password you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Note: Your password will not be visible.
trans-unit.target: Note: Your password will not be visible.

trans-unit.source: The output from the above command ends with a message that deployment is successful:
trans-unit.target: The output from the above command ends with a message that deployment is successful:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you make changes to your app, you can republish by selecting the **Commit All** check in VSCode and then enter the **git push azure master** command in **GitBash**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you make changes to your app, you can republish by selecting the **Commit All** check in VSCode and then enter the **git push azure master** command in **GitBash**.

trans-unit.source: View the API definition in the Azure preview portal
trans-unit.target: View the API definition in the Azure preview portal

trans-unit.source: Now that you have deployed an API to your API app, you can see the API definition in the Azure preview portal.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have deployed an API to your API app, you can see the API definition in the Azure preview portal.

trans-unit.source: You'll begin by restarting the gateway, which enables Azure to recognize that an API app's API definition has changed.
trans-unit.target: You'll begin by restarting the gateway, which enables Azure to recognize that an API app's API definition has changed.

trans-unit.source: The gateway is a web app that handles API administration and authorization for the API apps in a resource group.
trans-unit.target: The gateway is a web app that handles API administration and authorization for the API apps in a resource group.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, go to the **API APP** blade for the API app that you created earlier, and click the **Gateway** link.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, go to the **API APP** blade for the API app that you created earlier, and click the **Gateway** link.

trans-unit.source: You can now close this blade.
trans-unit.target: You can now close this blade.

trans-unit.source: In the **API APP** blade, click the **Restart**.
trans-unit.target: In the **API APP** blade, click the **Restart**.

trans-unit.source: In the **API APP** blade, click **API Definition**.
trans-unit.target: In the **API APP** blade, click **API Definition**.

trans-unit.source: The API Definition blade shows two methods.
trans-unit.target: The API Definition blade shows two methods.

trans-unit.source: If you don't see the GET and POST methods right away, wait a few seconds for Azure to refresh the app.
trans-unit.target: If you don't see the GET and POST methods right away, wait a few seconds for Azure to refresh the app.

trans-unit.source: Then, click **API Definition** in the **API APP** blade.
trans-unit.target: Then, click **API Definition** in the **API APP** blade.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, go to the **API APP HOST** blade for your API app and click **Browse**.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, go to the **API APP HOST** blade for your API app and click **Browse**.

trans-unit.source: Then, add **api/Contacts** to the end of your URL to view the contact details.
trans-unit.target: Then, add **api/Contacts** to the end of your URL to view the contact details.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you learned how to create an API app in Visual Studio Code.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you learned how to create an API app in Visual Studio Code.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Visual Studio Code, see [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Visual Studio Code, see [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/).

trans-unit.source: For information about API apps, see [What are API apps?](app-service-api-apps-why-best-platform.md)
trans-unit.target: For information about API apps, see [What are API apps?](app-service-api-apps-why-best-platform.md)
